Family member means a spouse, parent, grandparent, child, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, nephew, niece, father-in-law, motherin-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepparent, stepchild, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, or half sister. Gift means anything of value exceeding $0.00, including, but not limited to, food, lodging, transportation, personal services, gratuities, subscriptions, memberships, trips, loans, extensions of credit, forgiveness of debts, or advances or deposits of money. However, nothing in this article shall prohibit any commissioner or employee from having a business luncheon meeting with any person or other legal entity where the meal is paid for by such person or legal entity, which meal does not exceed $50.00. Lobbyist shall have the meaning defined in O.C.G.A. Â§ 21-5-70(6). Officer means the elected county commissioner and the heads of all agencies who are appointed by such commissioners. For purposes of this article, all officers are also employees as that term is defined herein. Person means an individual, partnership, committee, association, corporation, labor organization, or any other organization or group of individuals. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 26/188 (a) (b) (a) (b) (a) (b) (1) (2) Value means the actual retail price or cost attributable to a gift, less applicable taxes and gratuities, or a reasonable estimate based upon customary charges for like good or services in the locality. A series of tickets to sporting, entertainment, or similar events shall be valued as one gift. Entrance fees, admission fees, or other tickets shall be valued at the face value of the ticket or fee, excluding any portion attributable to a charitable contribution, if provided by a charitable organization. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 1(b)) Sec. 2-353. - Ethics ocer. The board of commissioners shall designate an ethics officer. The ethics officer shall take appropriate measures to ensure that the agency's employees become familiar with applicable ethics laws and policies, including the policies set forth in this article. Reserved. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 2) Sec. 2-354. - Conicts of interest. An employee of the board of commissioners shall make every effort to avoid even the appearance of a conflict of interest. An appearance of conflict exists when a reasonable person would conclude from the circumstances that the employee's ability to protect the public interest, or perform public duties, is compromised by personal interests. An appearance of conflict could exist even in the absence of a true conflict of interest. An employee of the board of commissioners shall recuse himself from any proceeding in which the employee's impartiality might reasonably be questioned due to the employee's personal or financial relationship with a participant in the proceeding. The term "participant" includes, but is not limited to, an owner, shareholder, partner, employee, resident, or agent of a business entity involved in the proceeding. If the employee is uncertain whether the relationship justifies recusal, then the employee shall disclose the relationship to the person presiding over the proceeding. The presiding officer shall determine the extent to which, if any, the employee will be permitted to participate. If the affected employee is the person presiding, then the vice-chairperson or such other substitute presiding officer shall make the determination. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 3) Sec. 2-355. - Gifts. Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section and as set forth hereinbefore, no employee, nor any person on his behalf, shall accept, directly or indirectly, any gift from any person with whom the employee interacts on official business, including, without limitation, lobbyists and vendors which exceeds $100.00. If a gift has been accepted which exceeds $100.00 it must be either returned to the donor or transferred to a charitable organization. Where appropriate for purposes of tradition, ceremony, or intergovernmental relations, or when acting as a representative of the board of commissioners, an employee may accept a gift in excess of $100.00 on behalf of the board of commissioners. If the gift retains a value exceeding $100.00, after its acceptance, the employee must: Maintain custody of the gift no longer than reasonably necessary to arrange for the transfer of custody of the gift to the board of commissioners or a charitable organization on behalf of such; File a report with the designated ethics officer no later than 30 days after receipt of the gift containing a description of the gift, the approximate monetary value thereof, the name and address of the person making the gift, the date the gift was made, and the disposition of the gift. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 4) Sec. 2-356. - Honoraria. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 27/188 (a) (b) (c) (d) (a) (b) No employee may accept any honoraria whatsoever. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 5) Sec. 2-357. - Expenses. An employee on whose behalf actual and reasonable expenses for food, beverages, travel, lodging, and registration are paid to permit the employee's participation in a meeting related to official or professional duties of the employee shall file a report no later than 30 days after such expenses are paid. The report shall be filed with the designated ethics officer. The report must contain a description of each expense, the monetary value thereof, the name and address of the person paying such expense, and the purpose, date, and location of the meeting. Notwithstanding this provision, the preferred practice is for agencies and not third parties to pay such expenses. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 6) Sec. 2-358. - Lobbying. The use of lobbyists will not be required or preferred as a way to obtain access to employees. Employees will strongly encourage any lobbyist wishing to meet with the board of commissioners or staff regarding his client and/or principal to bring a principal of his client to such meeting. Former employees should not use their former positions for financial or other personal gain or to influence legislation or procurement decisions. Employees shall decline to communicate on official government matters with any lobbyist who was an officer within the preceding one-year period. No agency shall be permitted to contract with any person to provide lobbying, as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. Â§ 21-5-70(5), services on behalf of that agency. Employees who promote or oppose the passage of any legislation by the board of commissioners, or any committee thereof, shall coordinate all such activities with the chairperson of the board of commissioners. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 7) Sec. 2-359. - Fair and equal access. Employees are required to afford all constituents fair and equal opportunity to express their concerns and ideas regarding the county programs and policies without regard to their political affiliation, sophistication, or affluence. Recommendations and decisions made by employees in the performance of their duties shall be made without bias. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 8) Sec. 2-360. - Employment/board service. Employees may serve for compensation any company of nonprofit organizations so long as services to such organizations would not have the potential to create a conflict and do not impair the employee's ability to discharge his public duties fully, faithfully and impartially. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 9) Sec. 2-361. - Political activities. Employees wishing to take part in political activities are responsible for complying with applicable federal and state law. Employees are prohibited from soliciting or knowingly accepting any campaign contribution in a governmental building or office. The term "accept" means to receive a contribution by personal hand-delivery from a contributor 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 28/188 (c) (a) (b) or his agent. This does not apply when a government-owned building or any portion thereof is rented for the specific purpose of holding a campaign fundraiser. Employees are permitted to express their opinions on political subjects and candidates and to take an active part in political campaigns outside of working hours, including the wearing of badges or buttons and displaying of bumper stickers and posters. Employees are encouraged to vote outside of working hours. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 10) Sec. 2-362. - Personal use of telephone and Internet access. Telephone use. Personal long-distance calls shall not be charged to the county telephones. Employees must use their personal long-distance credit card or other personal resource for this purpose. It is also inappropriate to use a county cellular telephone for personal calls. Internet access and use. County-provided Internet access is intended for public business. Employee use of the Internet may be recorded and monitored. No employee is permitted to use or access the Internet for pornographic, obscene, or other improper purposes. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 11) Sec. 2-363. - Miscellaneous. There may be unique or compelling circumstances warranting exceptions to or waivers from the policies set out in this article in certain individual cases. In those instances, prior written approval of the board of commissioners is required. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 12) Sec. 2-364. - Enforcement. The board of commissioners shall make a copy of this article available to all employees and shall institute procedures for its enforcement consistent with all applicable state laws. Employees who violate this article are subject to disciplinary action, including termination of employment, subject to review by the board of commissioners. The agency head of each agency shall be responsible to the chairperson for the faithful enforcement of this article, and shall report all alleged violations. (Res. of 3-8-2005, Â§ 13)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 6-1â6-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SALE OF MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE Sec. 6-31. - Licenses for the sale of malt beverages and wine. Retail licenses for the sale of malt beverages and wine in the county and permits for the wholesale distribution of malt beverages and wine in the county will be granted in the manner set out in this article. (Res. of 1-13-1998, Â§ I) Sec. 6-32. - Type of sale. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 29/188 (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) (8) (9) (a) (1) (2) (3) Malt beverages and wine sold in the county may be consumed on the premises of the retailer if said retailer has an onpremises license. Malt beverages and wine will be sold by package only in retail businesses with an off-premises license. Malt beverages and wine may be refrigerated and cold prior to retail sale. (Res. of 1-13-1998, Â§ II) Sec. 6-33. - Retail licensee qualications. The retail licensee under this article must be a person of good moral character and a citizen of the United States. This shall not apply to the honorably discharged members of the nations' armed forces who have returned to the county within the prescribed limit. The licensee shall not have been convicted within five years of the date of his application of a felony or any violation of the laws of this state, or any other state, relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages. The licensee shall be the owner of the premises for which the license is held or the holder of any lease thereon. The licensee shall be active in, and solely responsible for, the management and operation of the business for which the license is granted. The applicant shall make a sworn statement of his qualifications according to the requirements set forth in this section and shall place same on file with the county clerk before any license is issued. If the application covers a partnership, all members of the partnership must be qualified to obtain a license and must make sworn statements of these qualifications. No person shall be granted a license to engage in the sale of malt or vinous beverages at retail unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the board of commissioners that such person, or the officers and directors of any corporation, shall be of good character and shall have a law-abiding reputation in the county. Any misstatement or concealment of fact in the application shall be grounds for revocation of the license issued and shall make the applicant liable to prosecution for perjury under law. No person shall be granted a license who has been convicted of violating any state law or ordinance concerning alcoholic beverages within ten years. A fingerprint card must accompany all new applications. (Res. of 1-13-1998, Â§ III) Sec. 6-34. - Wholesale permits. Any wholesale dealer in malt beverages licensed by the state or the agent of such wholesale dealer shall be granted a permit to distribute such beverages in the county upon application for such permit to the county clerk and the presentation of evidence that he understands this article and the conditions under which retail licenses are issued. (Res. of 1-13-1998, Â§ IV) Sec. 6-35. - Regulations. No holder of a license authorizing the sale of malt beverages or wine at retail in the county, nor any agent or employee of the licensee, shall do any of the following upon the licensed premises: Knowingly sell beer or wine to a minor. Knowingly sell beer or wine to any person while such person is in an intoxicated condition. Sell beer or wine upon the licensed premises or permit beer or wine to be consumed thereon, on any day or at any time when such sale or consumption is prohibited by law. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 30/188 (4) (b) (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (c) (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (d) (1) (2) (3) (4) Permit on the licensed premises any disorderly conduct, breach of peace, or any lewd, immoral, or improper ente conduct or practices. In addition: It shall be the duty of the licensee to check the ID of all persons attempting to purchase malt beverages or wine. It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase beer or wine in the county. It shall be unlawful for any person or any parent to buy beer or wine and furnish it to a minor for consumption. No licensee shall sell any beer or wine to any person under the age of 21 years. It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, sell, or possess, for the purpose of sale, any malt beverages or wine where such person does not have a license from the county to sell or possess for sale such beverages. Malt beverages or wine shall be received at or delivered to the premises of the retail licensee by no other means than by a conveyance owned and operated by a wholesale dealer. Transportation of malt beverages or wine by any other means shall be grounds for revocation of the retail license. Dealers in malt beverages or wine with an off-premises license shall not engage in the sale of such beverages except between the hours of 12:00 midnight Monday through 12:00 midnight Saturday night, and shall not permit their places of business to be opened for the sale of such beverages on Sunday. Application. Before a person may file an application for a malt beverage and wine license, he must have first have applied to the state for a sales tax number. The application for a license to sell malt beverages and or wine shall include the following question: "Have you applied for a Georgia Sales Tax Number? If not, you must first apply for a number before you are eligible to apply for a license." Each applicant must answer the question in this subsection. On the first application for a license to sell malt beverages and or wine, the applicant must file with the county clerk a copy of his state license within days after the same is issued by the state, and on subsequent applications, the applicant must attach a copy of his application for a state license to his application for a county license. When a federal license is issued to an applicant, the applicant must file a copy of same with the county clerk within ten days of when it is issued. An applicant who fails to file such copy of his state license or state application and/or the federal license shall subject his license to being revoked by the board of commissioners. Any nightclub or place of business licensed to sell beer or wine for consumption on the premises of the business and located within the unincorporated area of the county shall: Not sell or offer for sale or allow the consumption of alcohol on the business premises of such premises from 12:00 midnight Saturday until 12:00 midnight Sunday night each and every weekend. Close the business at 12:00 midnight Saturday until 12:00 midnight Sunday night each and every weekend unless authorized to stay open later and at other times by other provisions of this article. If such nightclub and/or business which is licensed to sell beer and wine for consumption on the premises also serves prepared food for consumption on the premises, then, in that event, the nightclub or business shall be authorized to be open from 12:00 midnight Saturday until 1:00 a.m. Sunday morning and from 11:00 a.m. Sunday morning until 12:00 midnight Sunday for the sale of food and soft drinks, provided the beer or beer and wine is locked up at 12:00 midnight Saturday night, and provided no beer or beer and wine is sold or consumed on the premises after 12:00 midnight Saturday until 12:00 midnight, the following Sunday. Any person operating such business as enumerated above, who violates any of the terms of this article shall be guilty of a violation of this article, and, upon arrest and conviction in the magistrate court of the county, be 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 31/188 (5) (e) (f) (a) (b) (a) imprisoned in the county jail for a period not to exceed 60 days and/or a fine not to exceed $500.00 for each offense. Each time that any person operating a business fails to close as aforesaid, it shall be a new and distinct crime and may be charged with a new crime each time they fail to close as aforesaid. Any licensee operating such business or businesses as enumerated above, and who violates any of the terms of this article, may be charged with the violation and upon a hearing before the board of commissioners, and upon evidence of such violation, may have his license to sell beer or beer and wine revoked. A license shall be a mere grant or privilege to carry on business during the term of the license, subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this and subject to revocation with or without cause, and with or without notice or hearing. In case of revocation, the licensee shall not be entitled to a return of the unearned license fee. All such licenses shall have printed on the front these words: "This license is a mere privilege subject to be revoked and annulled by the Marion County Commissioners, with notice of hearing." Any violation of the provisions of this article shall be grounds for immediate revocation of a license by the board of commissioners without delay. (Res. of 1-13-1998, Â§ V) Sec. 6-36. - License fees, etc. The applicant for a wholesale license shall pay to the county clerk at the time of his license being issued the sum of $100.00 for malt beverages as an annual license fee for operation for one year beginning on January 1 of the subject year and ending December 31 of such year. The applicant for a retail license shall pay to the county clerk at the time his license is received the sum of $150.00 as an annual license fee for operation for one year beginning on January 1 of the subject year and ending December 31 of same for off-premises license. The applicant for an on-premises retail license shall pay to the county clerk the sum of $300.00 as an annual fee for operation for one year beginning on January 1 of the subject year and ending December 31 of such year. (Res. of 1-13-1998, Â§ VI) Sec. 6-37. - Local excise tax. There is hereby levied and imposed upon all authorized wholesale dealers selling malt beverages and wine within the county a specific excise tax as follows: Malt Beverages Tax (in dollars) 24/12 ounces 1.20 24/16 ounces 1.60 12/32 ounces 1.60 12/24 ounces 1.20 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 32/188 (b) (a) (b) (a) (b) (c) 24/7 ounces 0.70 Draft 1/2 barrel 6.00 Wine Per liter 0.22 Per gallon 0.80 Copies of all reports and taxes on sales made in the county, will be furnished the board of commissioners, monthly to be filed by the 15th day of the following month. (Res. of 1-13-1998, Â§ VII) Sec. 6-38. - Distance restrictions. Distance requirements. No license under this article shall be issued to any dealer where the place of business of the license is located within 50 yards of any public library or branch thereof, which is on the same side of the street as the establishment, or within 100 yards of any church, or within 200 yards of a school ground or college campus, except that the restrictions of the section shall not apply to private social clubs owning their own homes which have been chartered and in continuous operation for a period of 25 years prior to the date of the resolution from which this article is derived. The schools or colleges referred to herein shall include only such state, county, city, church or other schools as teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools or colleges of this state, and shall not include private schools or colleges wherein only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations or other special subjects are taught. Measurement. The distances set out in subsection (a) of this section shall be ascertained by measuring the distance along the route that a person ordinarily walks going directly from the entrance of the building of the licensee to the nearest library, church, school ground or college campus. (Res. of 1-13-1998, Â§ VIII) Sec. 6-39. - Administration. If the board of commissioners approves the application under this article, the county clerk shall issue an annual retail license to the applicant upon the payment of the license fee. A license to engage in the business of selling malt beverages or wine at retail shall not be transferable, except that in the case of the death of any person holding such a license, or any interest therein, in the discretion of the board of commissioners, the license may be transferred to the administrator, executor, or lawful heirs of the deceased person. It shall not be necessary for any dealer in malt beverages to make application for a permit for the renewal of an existing license. It shall be necessary, however, when there is any change of any kind in the ownership of any interest in the business to comply with the terms and provisions of this article. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 33/188 (d) (1) (2) (3) (a) (b) (c) (1) A copy of this article shall be given to all applicants for license upon their filing their applications with the county clerk. those applicants who have been approved by the board of commissioners shall be required to comply with the provisio article upon beginning operation of the establishment. (Res. of 1-13-1998, Â§ IX)

div.head: Chapter 10 - ANIMALS
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 10-1â10-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL Sec. 10-31. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Domesticated animal means any animal raised so as to live in close proximity to man. The term "domesticated animals" includes dogs and cats as well as varieties of poultry, livestock or reptiles, not meant for consumption. Domesticated animal at large means any domesticated animal not under the restraint of a person capable of controlling it on or off the premises of the owner. Owner means any person who owns, possesses, harbors, or keeps, or knowingly permits an animal to be harbored or kept or has an animal in his care, or who permits an animal to remain on or about his premises for more than three days. Public nuisance means any animal that unreasonably annoys humans, endangers the life or health of other animals or persons, or substantially interferes with the rights of citizens, other than their owners, to enjoyment of life or property. The term "public nuisance" means and includes, but is not limited to, any animal that: Damages the property of anyone other than its owner on numerous occasions; Attacks other domestic animals on numerous occasions; Unprovoked, attacks pedestrians or passersby on public property or any property not owned by the animal's owner. Vaccination means a protection against rabies by inoculation with antirabies vaccine, given in an amount sufficient to provide immunity from rabies for a minimum of one year. Sec. 10-32. - Vaccinations. No person shall own, keep, maintain, harbor, or permit to be kept or harbored, any dog or cat within the unincorporated area of the county unless the dog or cat is vaccinated as herein provided. All dogs and cats over three months of age within the unincorporated area of the county shall be vaccinated against rabies. Said rabies vaccination shall be administered by such person as is required by the laws of the state. It shall be the duty of each dog owner, possessor, or custodian to have a current rabies tag issued by a person authorized by the laws of the state on such animals. Silver rabies tags are current for the year stamped therein and the following year. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 34/188 (2) (d) (e) (a) (b) (a) (b) (a) (b) (c) (a) (b) (c) (d) Colored rabies tags are current for the year stamped therein and for the three following years. It shall be the duty of each dog owner, possessor or custodian to attach the rabies license tag to a collar, which shall be fastened around the dog's neck. The collar and rabies license shall be worn by the dog at all times. Failure to comply with this section shall be unlawful and shall be punishable as hereinafter provided. It shall be the duty of each cat owner, possessor, or custodian to have a current certificate or other evidence of inoculation and to produce such evidence when requested by the law enforcement officer or animal control officer. (Ord. of 2-14-2006, Â§ 1) Sec. 10-33. - Animals running at large. It shall be unlawful for stray, unclaimed dogs and/or cats, or dogs or cats whose owner, possessor, keeper or harborer cannot be determined, to run loose in the unincorporated area of the county. Any dog or cat in violation of subsection (a) of this section may be picked up by the sheriff of the county or the animal control officer and disposed of in accordance with the provisions hereinafter provided for. (Ord. of 2-14-2006, Â§ 2) Sec. 10-34. - Female dogs. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow a female dog, when in breeding season, to run loose on the public streets, roads, highways and other public places within the incorporated area of the county. Failure to comply with this section shall be unlawful and shall be punished as hereinafter provided. (Ord. of 2-14-2006, Â§ 3) Sec. 10-35. - Destruction and quarantine of animals. Dogs, cats and other animals, whether vaccinated or not, which have bitten a person, and those dogs, cats and other animals suspected of having rabies, or any dog or cat which has been bitten by an animal suspected of having rabies, shall promptly be confined in a cage strong enough to hold a rabid animal under all circumstances. The owner, possessor or custodian of said animal shall immediately notify the health department, the sheriff's office and the clerk of the board of commissioners of the county. If a dog or cat is suspected of having rabies or has been bitten by an animal suspected of having rabies, then the dog or cat shall be removed from the owner's premises to a veterinary hospital and there placed under observation for a period of two weeks, and shall only be released to the owner upon authorization of the custodial veterinarian. If a dog or cat is quarantined that is suspected of having rabies, and the dog or cat later comes down with rabies, then the rabid animal shall be promptly destroyed, and the dead animal turned over to the proper health officials. (Ord. of 2-14-2006, Â§ 4) Sec. 10-36. - Animal control ocer. The county may contract with an animal shelter or association that operates an animal shelter for said animal shelter or association to provide an animal control officer in enforcing the provisions of section 10-33 and to assist law enforcement officers and/or health officials in the enforcement of the provisions of sections 10-32 and 10-35 The animal control officer provided by said animal shelter or association shall serve without compensation from the county. The animal control officer shall have no arrest power and at no time restrain or interfere with any person or legal entity, nor enter onto private property except in the pursuit of stray dogs or cats or in assisting a law enforcement in the pursuit of a rabid animal. The animal control officer shall have the authority to catch and hold any stray, unclaimed dogs and cats as well as 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 35/188 (1) (2) (3) (4) dogs and cats whose owner cannot be ascertained, who are in violation of section 10-33 After catching any of said dogs and/or cats as described in subsection (d) of this section and also described in section 10-33, the animal control officer shall make every effort to find the owner, possessor, custodian or harborer of said animal, and return the animal to its owner, possessor, custodian or harborer. If, after catching any of said dogs and/or cats as set forth in subsection (d)(1) of this section, and the true owner, possessor, custodian or harborer cannot be determined, then the animal control officer shall quarantine said animal in the animal control shelter for a period of two weeks (14 days), and place an add in the legal organ of the county, with a description of said animal or animals with information sufficient for the public to know where to pick up the dog and/or cat. If the owner, possessor or harborer of said dog and/or cat does not come forward and claim said dog after said 14 day period, then, in that event, the animal control officer may put said dog up for adoption by the public, or the animal control officer shall destroy the animal in a humane manner. All costs of housing and/or destroying any impounded dogs and cats shall be born by the animal shelter or association contracting with the county, for the impounding of said dogs and cats. However, the animal shelter may charge the owner, possessor, custodian or harborer a daily fee for housing and caring for any impounded animal plus any vaccination and/or veterinarian costs to the owner. The animal shelter may charge an adoption fee plus any vaccination and veterinarian costs to any person wishing to adopt any such impounded animal. All fees must be first approved by the board of commissioners of the county. (Ord. of 2-14-2006, Â§ 5) Sec. 10-37. - Punishment for violations. Any person violating sections 10-32 and/or 10-35 may be charged and summoned by the sheriff of the county, or his lawful deputies, and tried in the magistrate court of the county, and upon conviction, may be fined by the magistrate court no less than $50.00 and no more than $500.00, and/or placed in the county jail for a term not to exceed 60 days. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate and new violation. (Ord. of 2-14-2006, Â§ 6) Secs. 10-38â10-59. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - HIGH-DENSITY LIVESTOCK AND POULTRY Sec. 10-60. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dwelling means an occupied or unoccupied structure designed to house human occupants. The structure must have a septic tank and either an operational well or public water to qualify. For the purposes of this article, the term "dwelling" includes, but is not limited to, structures such as meetinghouses, churches and commercial businesses. Examples of structures not meeting the definition are storage barns, workshops or sheds for livestock. The term "dwelling" does not include the operator's own house or a house constructed by operator. High-density livestock and poultry farming means intensive methods for producing animal products which include confinement of large numbers of animals in small containment areas. This would include, but is not exclusive to, poultry and/or rabbits in small cages or houses containing more than 100 animals, swine in small pens, and sheep and cattle in small lots. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 36/188 (a) (b) (a) Other high-density livestock production means all farm production activities which exceed the minimum herd size requiring compliance with waste treatment standards of the state department of natural resources are high-density development and classified as conditional uses requiring review by the planning commission and approval by the board of commissioners. Poultry house means a structure designed primarily for the housing of birds for commercial sale of eggs or birds. Poultry houses capable of handling more than 25,500 chickens will be considered as two poultry houses. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(C), Â§ 2.0, 6-11-1996) Sec. 10-61. - Penalties. Any violation of this article shall, upon conviction in the magistrate court of the county, be fined an appropriate amount not to exceed the sum of $100.00 for each violation. Each day the violation continues shall be a new offense. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(C), Â§ 9.0, 6-11-1996; Res. of 4-12-2005) Sec. 10-62. - Substantial completion. Facilities which have the base completed within 14 days from the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be considered existing prior to such effective date, provided at least 50 percent of the framing is complete 90 days after the base has been inspected, and the inspection has taken place within the 14-day period. If framing is not at this 50 percent stage of completion, the permit for existing facilities will be repealed and the operator must meet the criteria for new construction. Compliance with this section will be on a facility-by-facility basis. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(C), Â§ 3.0, 6-11-1996) Sec. 10-63. - Distance restrictions. Generally. No high-density livestock facility or poultry houses shall be erected less than 1,500 feet from an existing dwelling, or from any property located within a municipality zoned residential. City limits. No high-density livestock and poultry facility shall be erected or constructed within one mile of the existing corporate city limits of each of the municipalities located in the county. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(C), Â§ 4.0, 6-11-1996) Sec. 10-64. - Construction. No more than one high-density livestock facility or poultry house shall be built for each 5.0 acres of land, providing all other distances requirements have been met. Land must be continuous and not separated by country roads, state roads or rivers. For acreage calculation, roadways shall be included, as well as setback distances required under this article. The proposed operator shall be responsible for the preparation of a survey prepared by a registered surveyor and submitted to the administrator. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(C), Â§ 5.0, 6-11-1996) Sec. 10-65. - Permit. Required. All high-density livestock facilities must have a permit obtained from the board of commissioners. Facilities currently under construction will be deemed permitted provided the operator applies within 14 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived for a permit and the property is inspected and determined to be in substantial completion by the administrator. The permit shall remain current for the facility for as long as the facility remains in operation. Should the facility cease to operate for more than 12 consecutive months, the permit will no longer be valid. Should the facility be destroyed, the operator can reconstruct the facility no closer to the dwellings than the facility was prior to destruction. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 37/188 (b) (c) (a) (b) (c) (a) Permit fee. An operator obtaining a permit after the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall p time permit fee of $100.00 to the board of commissioners. Soil conservation recommendations. Prior to applying for a permit, an applicant shall contact soil conservation to obtain recommendations regarding soil nutrient content. A permit applicant must have a letter from soil conservation that the applicant has contacted soil conservation. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(C), Â§ 6.0, 6-11-1996) Sec. 10-66. - Appeals. Should operators disagree with the findings of the administrator, the operator or landowner shall have the opportunity for an appeal to the board of commissioners or a board established by the board of commissioners to hear such appeal. The appeal must be in writing and received by the county clerk no later than 30 days from the date in which the violation was reported to the operator. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(C), Â§ 7.0, 6-11-1996) Sec. 10-67. - Inspections. Inspections under this article shall be performed by the administrator within three working days after the operator has applied for a permit and requested an initial site inspection. A written report shall be provided to the operator with a copy maintained at the office of the board of commissioners. Applicants for permits under this article shall pay all expenses, including, but not limited to, registered surveying, engineering, mapping which may be involved in applying, and certifying compliance with the requirements of this article. The administrator shall assist an applicant in determining whether construction is in compliance with this article. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(C), Â§ 8.0, 6-11-1996)

div.head: Chapter 14 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 14-1. - Displaying location permits on mobile or prebuilt homes. The county board of tax assessors is granted the authority to write citations for the violation of not displaying location permits (decals) on all mobile homes or prebuilt mobile homes in the county. The citation is a misdemeanor and is settled in magistrate court within 30 days of the issuance (O.C.G.A. Â§ 48-5-493). Such citations shall be reviewed by the board of tax assessors before being turned over to magistrate court for processing. Editor's noteâ The adoption date of this section is not available. Sec. 14-2. - Address numbering. Required; specifications. Every person, business, establishment, congregation, group and all other legal entities, including outdoor recreation camps with an address in the unincorporated area of the county, shall exhibit light reflector numbers, such numbers to be at least three inches high, either on both sides of their mailbox, or on a sign with two sides with such reflector numbers on each side of the sign. The numbers to be used on such mailbox or sign shall be the same as the numbers assigned by the governing authority. If a sign is used, it must be hung so that it is easily read by an individual from an automobile traveling in either direction approaching said sign or address. All reflector numbers shall be installed right side up so that they can be easily read. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 38/188 (b) (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) (8) (a) (b) Penalty. Any person, business, establishment, congregation, group, outdoor recreation camp or other legal entity violat the provisions of this section may be given a summons and tried in the magistrate court of the county. Upon conviction person shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00, sentenced to a jail term of not more than 90 da or both, or any part thereof. (Res. of 1-14-2003) Secs. 14-3â14-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION CODES Sec. 14-31. - Adopted. The following codes, the latest edition as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs, shall be enforced by the county: Standard building code. Standard mechanical code. Standard gas code. Standard plumbing code. National Electrical Code. Standard fire prevention code. CABO One- and Two-Family Dwelling Code. Georgia State Energy Code for Buildings. State law referenceâ Authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, Â§Â§ II, III(a)(12); construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. Â§ 8-2-1 et seq.; minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. Â§ 8-2-25. Sec. 14-32. - Compliance. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the construction or erection of any building, whether commercial, business or residential unless such construction is accomplished in compliance with the various construction codes adopted by this article, except farm buildings and sheds. Sec. 14-33. - Enforcement. When reference is made to the duties of certain officials named in the various construction codes adopted by this article, the building official shall be deemed to be the responsible official for the enforcement of such codes. Sec. 14-34. - Penalty for violation. Generally. Any person violating any provision of the various construction codes adopted by this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-17 Suspension of license. A conviction of any provision of the various construction codes adopted by this article shall automatically suspend the business license of the offending contractor. The license may be reinstated by an application to the county upon a showing of good cause. Sec. 14-35. - Permit and inspection fees. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 39/188 (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) Permit and inspection fees and any other charges imposed or due under the various construction codes adopted by this article shall be as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. Sec. 14-36. - Exemption from self-inspection of sewer lines by plumbers and utility contractors. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. Â§ 8-2-26(d), the board of commissioners exempt the county from the provisions of O.C.G.A. Â§ 8-2-26(d), regarding self-inspection of sewer lines by plumbers and utility contractors. (Res. of 5-28-1996) Secs. 14-37â14-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WATER CONSERVATION RESTRICTIONS Sec. 14-61. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling but shall not include a hotel or motel. (Ord. of 11-12-1991, Â§ 1) Sec. 14-62. - Construction restrictions. On or after July 1, 1991, no construction may be initiated within the county for any residential building of any type which: Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this subsection shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; Employs a showerhead that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of 1.0 gallons of water per flush; Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute; or Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. (Ord. of 11-12-1991, Â§ 2) Sec. 14-63. - Construction requirements. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 40/188 (a) (1) (2) (3) (4) a. b. c. (b) (a) (b) On or after July 1, 1992, there shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated with the county for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of section 14-62. (Ord. of 11-12-1991, Â§ 3) Sec. 14-64. - Application of article to repairs and renovations. The requirements of section 14-62 shall apply to any residential construction initiated after July 1, 1991, and to any commercial construction initiated after July 1, 1992, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers, or both. (Ord. of 11-12-1991, Â§ 4) Sec. 14-65. - Exemptions. Generally. New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 14-62, 14-63 and 14-64 when: The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; Such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design, or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this article were installed; Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or Units to be installed are: Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or Toilets for juveniles. Reserved. (Ord. of 11-12-1991, Â§ 5) Sec. 14-66. - Enforcement; penalty. Enforcement. This article shall be enforced by the office of the building inspector of the county. Citations for violations may be issued by the chief building inspector of the county. Penalty. Any person violating this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-17 (Ord. of 11-12-1991, Â§ 6) Sec. 14-67. - Conicts. All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are repealed. (Ord. of 11-12-1991, Â§ 7)

div.head: Chapter 18 - BUSINESSES
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 18-1. - Door-to-door sale of meat, groceries or other goods. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 41/188 (a) (b) (c) (a) License requirement; cost. Every person who engages in the door-to-door sale of meat, groceries or other goods, ware merchandise in the county shall be first required to obtain a license from the county clerk, at a cost of $50.00 for each person in such activity. Penalty. Any person who engages in the door-to-door sale of meat, groceries or other goods, wares and merchandise without a license shall be guilty of a violation of this section, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-17. Each sale shall constitute a new and separate offense. Exemptions. There shall be excluded from and exempted from the requirements of this section church and religious organization, all charitable and nonprofit organizations or firms, and all associations affiliated with a school, college or other institution of learning. Editor's noteâ The adoption date of this section is not available. Secs. 18-2â18-29. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PAWNBROKERS Sec. 18-30. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Owner means any person, partner or stockholder owning 25 percent or more of a business. Pawnbroker means a person, whether owner, manager or employee, whose business is to lend money on security of personal property deposited with him or left in pawn. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-32 Sec. 18-31. - Penalty. Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished and may be charged upon a citation, or accusation to the Magistrate Court of Marion County, Georgia, and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $100.00 and no more than $500.00 and/or 60 days in the county jail. Each day of a violation of this article shall be a separate and new offense. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-40 Sec. 18-32. - Applicability. This article shall apply to all pawnbrokers in the county. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-31 Sec. 18-33. - License fees. All businesses involving pawnbrokers shall pay an annual license fee of $250.00 to the clerk of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-33 Sec. 18-34. - Revocation of licenses. Generally. Licenses issued under this article may be revoked upon a conviction of the licensee or an employee of the licensee or plea of guilty or nolo contendere by the licensee or an employee of the licensee in court of a violation of 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 42/188 (b) (1) (2) (3) (4) (1) a. b. (2) any of this article's provisions; upon a conviction of the licensee or an employee of the licensee or plea of guilty or nolo contendere by the licensee or an employee of the licensee in any state of any felony involving any offense or any misdemeanor involving theft-related offenses; or if the licensee or an employee of the licensee violates any of the provisions of this article. Procedures. The following procedures shall be followed in the revocation of licenses under this article: Notice shall be given to the holder of a license at least two weeks in advance that the board of commissioners, will hear a recommendation that the license be revoked, and this notice shall include the specific grounds on which this recommendation is made. The clerk of commissioners shall notify the license holder, the director of finance, and the sheriff, or the director of public safety, as to the time that a recommendation for revocation will be heard. The board of commissioners shall hear a recommendation for revocation at one of its regular meetings, at which time the holder of a license and any other interested parties will be heard. No license shall be revoked until a majority of the board of commissioners so decides at the time of or subsequent to the hearing on the recommendation for revocation. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-34 Sec. 18-35. - Character requirements. No license shall be issued to or renewed for any person who conducts a business in which the owner or manager or any employee has, within five years of issuance or renewal, been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to any felony involving any offense or any misdemeanor involving theft-related offenses, in any state, and all licensees shall submit the identity of all owners and managers and employees to the county sheriff's department and to the revenue collection division on a continuing basis as changes occur for the purpose of allowing a complete check in order that these character requirements are fulfilled. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-35 Sec. 18-36. - Location of business. All businesses regulated by this article shall be conducted at an identifiable street address which shall be provided on a license or renewal application which itself shall be turned over to the county sheriff's department, and no licensee shall change the address for any business without giving advance notice to both the revenue collection division and the county sheriff's department. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-36 Sec. 18-37. - Requirements upon receiving pawn or purchasing items. All businesses regulated by this article shall fulfill the following requirements when receiving in pawn or purchasing: Require the pawner or seller to positively identify himself by driver's license, military ID card, alcohol beverage card, Social Security number, or any other means of identification that contains the following information: Birth date, sex, race, address, telephone number; and Any other relevant physical descriptive information; all of which will be contained on a form prescribed and provided to the business by the county sheriff's department. Record on the same form which describes the pawner or seller a complete description of the merchandise pawned or purchased, including kind, style, material, color, design, and all identifying names, marks and numbers, and any distinguishing marks such as initials or serial numbers, as well as the time it was obtained 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 43/188 (3) (4) (1) (2) (3) by the pawner or purchases, and from whom it was obtained. For a period of seven days from the date of pawning or purchasing, post in a clearly visible or accessible place on the premises designated in the license for doing business the forms containing the information in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, and hold on these at the premises in a place readily available for inspection by both law enforcement officials and the general public, all of these designated items in the same condition as they existed when first pawned or purchased. Require the pawner or seller to sign the county sheriff's department form on a signature line which shall be preceded by the following sentence: "I do solemnly swear or affirm that the information provided by me on this form is true and correct." Adjacent to the pawner's or seller's signature there shall be affixed the right thumbprint of the pawner or seller, and the pawnbroker shall use ink and pad approved by the county sheriff's department. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-37 Sec. 18-38. - Daily reports. The sheriff or his deputy shall require pawnbrokers to make daily written reports on all of their purchases or items received in pawn, and these reports may contain, in addition to such descriptive information as is required in the sheriff's department forms, information concerning the price paid for specific items. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-38 Sec. 18-39. - Receiving in pawn or buying from minors prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any business regulated by this article to receive in pawn or trade or to buy from minors goods of any character or description. A minor, for the purpose of this article, is an individual 17 years of age or under. (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01), Â§ 18-39 Sec. 18-40. - Pawn shop weekly report. Itemize all pawns taken in within the past week giving the following information about each pawn: Name, address, social security number and telephone number of each person who pawned any item with you. Full description of each item pawned including, but not limited to make, model and serial number. Attach a copy of the thumb print of each person making a pawn. I certify that the above constitutes each and every person or legal entity who has pawned any items with me and a description of each and every item pawned with me during the past week. ____________ Owner or Representative (Ord. of 12-12-2006(01)) Secs. 18-41â18-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - POOL TABLES AND GAMING DEVICES Sec. 18-71. - Licensing of pool tables. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 44/188 (a) (b) (a) (b) (1) (2) a. b. c. d. e. f. g. License requirement. All persons having and operating pool tables in a public business or their homes whereby a fee is charged for the use of such pool tables shall be required to purchase a license from the board of commissioners; and such license shall cost $50.00 for the first pool table and $25.00 for each additional pool table. Such license shall be good for one year and shall begin on January 1 of each year and shall end on December 31. Penalty. Any person operating a pool table as provided in subsection (a) of this section without such license will be guilty of a violation of this section and, upon conviction, shall be fined not more than $500.00. (Res. of 12-6-1988) Sec. 18-72. - Licensing of video games. License requirement. All persons having and operating video games in a public business or in their homes whereby a fee is charged for the use of such video games shall be required to purchase a license from the board of commissioners; such license shall cost $25.00 for each video game. Such license shall be good for one year and shall begin on January 1 of each year and shall last until December 31. Penalty. Any person operating a video game as provided in subsection (a) of this section without such license will be guilty of a violation of this section and, upon conviction, shall be fined not more than $500.00. (Res. of 12-6-1988) Secs. 18-73â18-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - OUTDOOR ENTERTAINMENT FOOTNOTE(S): Editor's noteâ The adoption date of this article is not available. Sec. 18-101. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Entertainment. The term "entertainment" means any noise or music emanating from or produced by any person, group, instrument or instrumental recording or audio visual device used for the performance of entertainment for an audience, regardless of whether an admission fee or remuneration is paid, and regardless of whether for profit or charity. The term "entertainment" does not mean: Any music played over an installed music system solely during the dining of customers in a restaurant and played at a level less than normal conversation; Any music or noise at private, social functions such as wedding receptions, barbecues, and the like; Any music or noise from any school events or school athletics; Any noise or music from the use of any public property; Any noise or music from nonprofit, religious or charitable organizations conducting annual events, or occasional fundraising events, or sounds emitted during normal religious worship and/or activity; Any noise or music from political rallies or meetings; Any noise or music from occasional or periodic commercial sales promotions; and (1) 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 45/188 h. (a) (b) (a) (b) (c) (a) (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (b) Any noise or music from seasonal holiday-related events for which the main attraction or draw thereof is no Outdoor means any area outside the exterior walls and covering roof of any building. The term "outdoor" shall also include, but not be limited to, any amphitheater, pavilion, porch, veranda, courtyard, deck, patio, pool or tent. Sec. 18-102. - Penalties. Generally. Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction in the magistrate court of this county, shall be fined in an amount up to $1,000.00, imprisoned up to 60 days, or both, for each violation, as provided for by state law. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense and shall subject such person to a fine or incarceration specified by this section for each such offense. Revocation of licenses. Notwithstanding any fines which may be levied or punishment imposed by the magistrate court, the board of commissioners shall have the right to revoke any business, alcohol or other license issued under any county ordinance for violation of this article. Sec. 18-103. - Prohibited conduct. Outdoor entertainment shall be not permitted in the county at any time. Outdoor entertainment is prohibited in all zoning districts. No audience participation events such as wet tee shirt contests, bikini contestss, mud wresting or the like, whether inside a building or outdoors, as defined in this article, shall be allowed. Secs. 18-104â18-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - LOGGING AND PULPWOOD HARVESTING; USE OF COUNTY RIGHTS-OF-WAY Sec. 18-131. - Security bond or letter of credit. Prior to beginning a tree harvesting operation in the county, all timber buyers shall post a security bond or a letter of credit in the amount of $2,500.00 with the county clerk for each separate tract of land from which trees are to be removed. For each such tract, the logger shall also provide: His name, address and telephone number. The name, address and telephone number of the foreman on each tract. The name, address and telephone number of the owner of each tract. The approximate location of the site for access to county roads for each tract. The anticipated date for commencement of removal of trees for each tract. The anticipated date for completing the removal of trees for each tract. Upon notification, the superintendent of public works shall inspect the site to determine if a culvert is required along such county right-of-way and the size and length of culvert, if any is required. If it is determined that a culvert is needed, it must be installed by the operator under the supervision of the director of public works. When the superintendent of public works makes his initial inspection of the site, the existing condition of the access point will be documented. All access points shall be constructed at an angle leading in the direction in which the log truck and/or pulpwood truck is exiting so that the truck shall not be required to make a sharp turn when the truck enters the county roadway. (Ord. of 9-10-2002, Â§ I) 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 46/188 (a) (b) (a) (b) (c) (d) (e) (f) (g) (h) (a) (b) (c) (d) (e) (f) Sec. 18-132. - Posting of one security bond by parent tree harvesting operations. If a parent tree harvesting operation has more than one tree harvesting operation in the county, then the parent tree harvesting operation may post one security bond or letter of credit to cover all of its tree harvesting operations in the county. Should a security bond or letter of credit be reduced by payment for damages to a road right-of-way or roadway caused by one or more of the tree harvesting operations operating under the parent tree harvesting operation, then the board of commissioners may require additional security bonds or letters of credit. (Ord. of 9-10-2002, Â§ I(B)) Sec. 18-133. - Regulations during operations. All logging or pulpwood loading operations shall be conducted at a loading site off the county rights-of-way and behind the established ditch line of county roads. Loading or skidding of logs will not be permitted on county roads. When a log truck leaves the loading site, it shall take the route that is nearest to a state or federal highway, and then travel along the state or federal highway to its destination or to a point outside of the county. Ditches shall be kept clear of all debris or residue at all times to allow for proper drainage. County roads at the access site shall be kept serviceable at all times for the passing public, emergency vehicles, school busses, mail carriers, etc. Operators will use crushed stone or some other material, if necessary, on access roads to prevent the transport of excessive amounts of mud from the operations area onto county roads. The county superintendent of public works, with the concurrence of the board of commissioners, has the authority to grant exceptions to the rules set out in this section. The board of commissioners hereby authorizes the superintendent of public works to order all logging operations to cease if it is determined that a timber buyer is failing to comply with this article. (Ord. of 9-10-2002, Â§ II) Sec. 18-134. - Concluding operations. Operators shall give oral or written notification upon completion of operations to the county public works department or the county commissioners' office within 72 hours. Harvesters may remove culverts installed by same upon completion of their operations. Upon site inspection by the county public works department and the determination that the road and access site are in a proper state of repair from harvesting operations, the superintendent shall provide a written notice of release of liability to the operator within ten days of notification from the operator. Should said notice of the release of liability not be made on a timely basis, operator shall not be held responsible or liable under this article. If it is determined by the superintendent of the county public works department either during or at the conclusion of operations that the county road and access site are not in a proper state of repair, the operator shall have ten days to correct the site, at the operator's expense, or to appeal the decision. Upon receipt of a written appeal, the board of commissioners shall have five days to impanel an arbitration board. The arbitration board shall consist of three people from the county: one person selected by the board of commissioners, one person selected by the operator, and one person mutually agreed upon by the two persons selected. Once the arbitration board has been selected, the arbitration board shall have no more than 30 days from the receipt of the letter of appeal in which to reach a decision. The decision of the arbitration board shall be final. Failure to comply with the above requirements for repairs will give the county the right to make the repairs and 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 47/188 charge the expense therefor to the operator and deduct said repairs from the $2,500.00 deposit. If the deposit is insufficient to pay for said costs of repairs, then the timber buyer and/or operator shall be billed for the excess. (Ord. of 9-10-2002, Â§ III) Sec. 18-135. - Penalty. Violations of any provisions of this article shall result in a fine up to $1,000.00 or imprisonment up to six months in the probate court of the county. (Ord. of 9-10-2002, Â§ I)

div.head: Chapter 22 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 22-1. - National Incident Management System (NIMS) adopted by reference. The county hereby adopts the National Incident Management System (NIMS) as established under HSPD 5 and the unified command system as established under O.C.G.A. 38-3-57 as its system of preparing for and responding to disaster incidents, and directs all incident managers and response organizations in the county to train and exercise and use these systems in their response operations. (Res. of 5-9-2004) Secs. 22-2â22-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CIVIL DEFENSE Sec. 22-31. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Civil defense means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions, other than the functions for which the state and federal governments are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters caused by enemy nuclear attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or by acts of nature, fire, explosion, civil disorders or other causes. Civil defense functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, law enforcement services, medical services, health services, rescue services, engineering services, warning services, communications, defense from radiological fallout, welfare services, evacuation (when and where necessary), emergency transportation, plant and utility protection, restriction of public utility services, and other functions related to protection and well being of the population of the county, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to preparation for and the carrying out of the functions set forth in this definition. (Res. of 12-1-1970, Â§ I) Sec. 22-32. - Penalties. Any violation of any provision of this article, or any rule, order, or regulation made pursuant to this article, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable as a misdemeanor. (Res. of 12-1-1970, Â§ VI) 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 48/188 (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) (a) Sec. 22-33. - Oce of the county civil defense director. In agreement with the governing officials of cities and/or towns within the county, there is hereby established the county civil defense office. The chairperson and commissioners of the board of commissioners, with concurrence of the officials of cities and towns within the county, shall nominate, for appointment by the governor, a director of civil defense for the entire county. When appointed, the civil defense director is charged: To represent the governing official of the county and cities and/or towns therein on matters pertaining to civil defense. With assisting county and city officials in organizing county, and where required, city departments, for emergency operations. With developing, in conjunction with other county departments, the county plan for emergency functions set forth in section 22-31. Such plan will be in consonant with the state emergency plan and shall be submitted to the board of commissioners for approval and then to the state director for approval. With maintaining the civil defense office in carrying out the day-to-day administration of the county civil defense and disaster program including the rendering of required reports to the state civil defense office. With rendering reports such as financial, daily activity, etc., as required by governing officials, in keeping with good business practices. With procuring, with authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the county emergency operating center. During periods of a declared emergency, and under the supervision of county governing officials, with coordinating the activities of the county emergency operating center staff. (Res. of 12-1-1970, Â§ II) Sec. 22-34. - County civil defense organization. Organizational structure by county departments and agencies.
