div.head: Chapter 26 - ENVIRONMENT
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 26-1â26-59. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - GROUNDWATER RECHARGE AREA PROTECTION Sec. 26-60. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Aquifer means any stratum (rock layer) or zone of rock beneath the surface of the earth capable of containing or producing water from a well. Groundwater recharge area means an area of the earth's surface where water infiltrates the ground, thereby replenishing the groundwater supplies within an aquifer. The term "groundwater recharge area" is synonymous with the term "aquifer recharge area." Pollution susceptibility means the relative vulnerability of groundwater to pollution from chemical spills, leaching of pollutants from dump sites, animal waste from agricultural operations or pollution generated by other human activities. Pollution susceptibility maps means maps prepared by the state department of natural resources that show the relative susceptibility of groundwater to pollution. Pollution susceptibility maps categorize the land areas of the state into areas of high, medium and low groundwater pollution potential. Significant groundwater recharge areas means areas mapped by the state department of natural resources in Hydrologic Atlas 18 (1989 edition). Mapping of recharge areas is based on outcrop area, lithology (chemical nature and form of rock), soil type and thickness, slope, density of lithologic contacts, geologic structure, presence of "karst" topography (sinkholes, caves and fissures associated with limestone and other carbonate rocks), and potentiometric surfaces. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 11) Sec. 26-61. - Penalties. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 53/188 (a) (b) (1) (2) (3) (1) Any person who commits, takes part in or assists in any violation of any provision of this article shall be fined not more than $500.00 for each offense, or up to 60 days in jail. Each violation shall be a separate offense and, in the case of a continuing violation, each day's continuance shall be deemed to be a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 5) Sec. 26-62. - Findings of fact. In order to provide for the health, safety and welfare of the public and to promote a healthy economic climate in the county and surrounding communities, it is essential that public drinking water resources of high quality be ensured. For this reason, it is necessary to protect the subsurface water resources in the county and surrounding communities rely upon such resources as sources of public water. Groundwater resources are contained within aquifers, which are permeable rock strata occupying vast regions of the subsurface. These aquifers are replenished by infiltration of surface water runoff in zones of the surface known as groundwater recharge areas. Groundwater is susceptible to contamination when unrestricted development occurs within significant groundwater recharge areas. It is, therefore, necessary to manage land use within groundwater recharge areas to ensure that pollution threats to water resources are minimized. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 1.2 Sec. 26-63. - Objectives. The objectives of this article are to: Protect groundwater quality by restricting land uses that generate, use or store dangerous pollutants in recharge areas; Protect groundwater quality by limiting density of development; and Protect groundwater quality by ensuring that any development that occurs within the recharge area shall have no adverse effect on groundwater quality. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 1.3 Sec. 26-64. - Establishment of groundwater recharge area district. A groundwater recharge area district is established which shall correspond to all lands in the unincorporated areas of the county, outside the City of Buena Vista, that are mapped and designated as significant recharge areas by the state department of natural resources in Hydrologic Atlas 18, 1989 edition. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 2) Sec. 26-65. - Determination of pollution susceptibility. Each recharge area shall be determined to have a pollution susceptibility of high, medium or low based on the groundwater pollution susceptibility map prepared by the state department of natural resources. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 3) Sec. 26-66. - Permit requirements and enforcement. No building permit, rezoning request or subdivision plan will be approved by the permitting officer unless the permit, request or plan is in compliance with the groundwater protection standards set forth in this article. Enforcement. The permitting officer, his agent, officers and employees shall have authority to enter upon 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 54/188 a. b. c. d. e. f. (2) a. b. c. d. e. f. (3) privately owned land for the purpose of performing their assigned duties and responsibilities under this article and may take or cause to be made such examinations, surveys or sampling as the permitting officer deems necessary. The permitting officer may require a bond with surety and conditions sufficient to secure compliance with the conditions set forth in the permit. The particular amount and conditions of the bond shall be consistent with the purposes of this article. In the event of a breach of any condition of any such bond, the permitting officer may institute an action in a court of competent jurisdiction upon such bond and prosecute the same to judgment and execution. The permitting officer shall have authority to enforce this article; issue permits under this article; and address violations or threatened violations of this article by issuance of violation notices, administrative orders and civil and criminal actions. All costs, fees and expenses in connection with such actions may be recovered as damages against the violator. Law enforcement officials or other officials having police powers in the jurisdiction shall have authority to assist the permitting officer in enforcement. The permitting officer shall have the authority to issue cease and desist orders in the event of any violation of this article. Cease and desist orders may be appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction, as identified in this article. When the permitting officer determines that a building or other structure has been constructed in violation of this article, the violator may, at the discretion of the permitting officer, be required to remove the structure. When removal of vegetative cover, excavation or fill has taken place in violation of this article, the violator may be required to restore the affected land to its original contours and to restore vegetation, as far as practicable. Permit review and site plan requirement. With the exception of certain exempted activities identified in subsection (4) of this section, applications for a development permit within the groundwater recharge area district shall include a site plan providing the following information: A map, drawn to a scale of one inch equals 50 feet, showing all planned improvements including the width, depth and length of all existing and proposed structures, roads, water courses and drainage ways, water lines, wastewater and stormwater facilities and utility installations. Location, dimensions and area of all impervious surfaces, both existing and proposed, on the site. The orientation and distance from the boundaries of the proposed site to the nearest bank of an affected perennial stream or water body. Elevations of the site and adjacent lands within 200 feet of the site at contour intervals of no greater than five feet. Location and detailed design of any spill and leak collection systems designed for the purpose of containing hazardous or toxic materials which may be released accidentally. Calculations of the amount of cut and fill proposed and cross sectional drawings showing existing and proposed grades in areas of fill or excavation. Elevations, horizontal scale and vertical scale must be shown on cross sectional drawings. Activities to comply with site plan. All development activities or site work conducted after approval of the site plan shall conform with the specifications of the site plan. Significant changes to the site plan that would alter the amount and velocity of stormwater runoff from the site, increase the amount of impervious surface within the development, alter the overall density of development, result in a considerable increase in the amount of excavation, fill or removal of vegetation during construction or otherwise result in an alteration of the overall 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 55/188 (4) a. b. c. (5) (6) a. b. (a) (b) (1) (2) (3) (c) (d) appearance of the development as proposed can be amended only with the approval of the permitting officer. Minor changes, such as the realignment of streets or minor alterations to drainage structures and other infrastructure to meet unexpected conditions, are exempted from this requirement. Exemptions to site plan requirements. The following activities and developments are exempt from the requirement for detailed site plans: Single-family detached homes constructed within a subdivision of fewer than five parcels. Repair to a facility that is part of a previously approved and permitted development. Construction of minor structures, such as sheds or additions to single-family residences. Review procedures. The application shall be made to the permitting officer and shall be reviewed within 14 days. The review period shall begin with the permitting officer's written determination that the application is complete. The review period shall include the preparation of findings (approval, conditional approval or disapproval) by the permitting officer. The applicant will receive written notification of the findings of the permitting officer. If the review process is not completed and written findings released within 30 days, the application is considered to be approved. Decisions of the permitting officer may be appealed to the board of commissioners. Duration of permit validity. If construction described in the development permit has not commenced within six months from the date of permit issuance, the permit shall expire. The permitting officer is not required to notify the permittee of the pending expiration of the permit. If construction described in the development permit is suspended or abandoned after work has commenced, the permit shall expire six months after the date work ceased. The permitting officer is not required to notify the permittee of the pending expiration of the permit. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 4) Sec. 26-67. - Groundwater protection standards. Requirement for pollution susceptibility area. For all pollution susceptibility areas, new waste disposal facilities must have synthetic liners and leachate collection systems. New agricultural waste impoundment sites. New agricultural waste impoundment sites shall be lined if they are within: A high pollution susceptibility area; A medium pollution susceptibility area and exceed 15 acre-feet; or A low pollution susceptibility area and exceed 50 acre-feet. At a minimum, the liner shall be constructed of compacted clay having a thickness of one-foot, and a vertical hydraulic conductivity of less than 5 by 10 cm/sec or other criteria established by the U.S. Department of Agriculture Natural Resources Conservation Service. Land disposal of municipal/household solid waste or hazardous waste. Land disposal of municipal/household solid waste or hazardous waste shall not be permitted within any significant groundwater recharge area. Handling of hazardous materials in significant groundwater recharge areas. For all significant groundwater recharge areas, the handling, storage and disposal of hazardous materials, as identified in section 312 of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, as amended (42 USC 6901 et seq.), excluding underground storage tanks, and in amounts of 10,000 pounds or more on any one day, shall take place on an impermeable surface having spill and leak protection approved by the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division, and in conformance with local fire prevention code requirements. -7 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 56/188 (e) (f) (g) (h) (i) (j) (1) a. b. c. (2) (a) (b) (1) (2) (3) Aboveground chemical or petroleum storage tanks. For all significant groundwater recharge areas new, aboveground c petroleum storage tanks larger than 650 gallons must have secondary containment for 110 percent of tank volume, or percent of the largest tank in a cluster of tanks. Such tanks used for agricultural purposes are exempt from this require provided they comply with applicable federal regulations. New wastewater treatment basins in high pollution susceptibility areas. For high pollution susceptibility areas, new wastewater treatment basins shall have an impermeable liner approved by the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division. Stormwater infiltration basins. For high pollution susceptibility areas, no new stormwater infiltration basins may be constructed. Wastewater spray irrigation systems and land application of wastewater sludge. For high pollution susceptibility areas, the use of wastewater spray irrigation systems and the land application of wastewater sludge shall be practiced in accordance with state department of natural resources criteria for slow rate land treatment. An application for a development permit for activities involving wastewater spray irrigation or land application of wastewater sludge must be accompanied by proof that the applicant has received a land application system permit from the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division. Minimum lot sizes and septic systems generally. Construction shall not proceed on any building or structure to be served by an on-site sewage management system until the county health department approves the proposed sewage management system as meeting requirements outlined in section M of the state department of human resources (DHR) manual for on-site sewage management systems, incorporated herein by reference, and the required building permits have been issued. Minimum lot size requirements in areas of significant groundwater recharge. The following minimum lot size requirements apply to on-site sewage management systems in areas of significant groundwater recharge. Minimum lot sizes shall be based on application of table MT-1 of the referenced DHR manual: 150 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size calculated based on application of DHR table MT-1 if they are within a high pollution susceptibility area; 125 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size calculated based on application of DHR Table MT-1 if they are within a medium pollution susceptibility area; 110 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size calculated based on application of DHR table MT-1 if they are within a low pollution susceptibility area. The minimums set forth in subsections (j)(1), (2) and (3) of this section may be increased based on consideration of factors such as those enumerated in section M of the state department of human resources manual for on-site sewage management systems, paragraphs 1A-1F. All final decisions of the board of commissioners concerning approval, conditional approval or denial of a permit shall be reviewable in the county superior court. Alternative actions. Based on these proceedings and the decision of the court the board of commissioners may, within the time specified by the court, elect to: Institute negotiated purchase or condemnation proceedings to acquire an easement or fee interest in the applicant's land; Approve the permit application with lesser restrictions or conditions (i.e., grant a variance); or Institute other appropriate actions ordered by the court that fall within the jurisdiction of the board of 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 57/188 (1) a. commissioners. The regulations in this article may, from time to time, be amended in accordance with procedures and requirements in the general statutes and as new information becomes available. The county board of tax assessors shall consider the requirements of the regulations in this article in determining the fair market value of land. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 9) Sec. 26-71. - Section M of manual for on-site sewage management systems. The text set forth in this section is from the state department of human resources manual for on-site sewage management systems, section M, pages M-1 and M-2, and is included here for convenience only. In the event of any conflict between the following text and the referenced manual, the referenced manual shall govern: Lot sizing. Larger lot sizes may be required to meet the requirements of this manual depending on the proposed development of the property. County boards of health and/or county zoning authorities may require larger minimum lot sizes; the larger minimum lot sizes will take precedence. Single-family dwellings. Area requirements for multiple dwellings on a single recorded lot, where not prohibited by local zoning, must be provided in multiples of the following minimum lot sizes for each dwelling to be constructed on the recorded lot. Subdivisions and individual lots. New homes served by septic tank and absorption field systems shall be on lots having the following minimum size limitations as identified in table MT-1: 150 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size of table MT-1 if lot is within a high pollution susceptibility area; 125 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size of table MT-1 if lot is within a medium pollution susceptibility area; 110 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size of table MT-1 if lot is within a low susceptibility area. Mobile home parks. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, appendix) Secs. 26-72â26-99. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WETLAND PROTECTION Sec. 26-100. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Generalized wetland map means a map showing the general locations of wetlands within the unincorporated areas of the county. The generalized wetland map used at the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived is the National Wetlands Inventory as published by the United States Department of Interior. Hydric soils means soils that form as a result of saturated soils conditions. A list of these soils is maintained by the USDA, Natural Resources Conservation Service. Hydrology means the science dealing with the properties, distribution, and circulation of water on the surface of the land, in the soil and underlying rocks, and in the atmosphere. Hydrophytic vegetation means macrophytic plants tolerant of or dependent on saturated soil conditions. Jurisdictional determination means an official, written statement or map signed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, stating whether a certain specified site is a wetland or is in a wetland. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 61/188 (a) (b) (a) Jurisdictional wetland means a wetland area that meets the definitional requirements for wetlands as determined by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Regulated activity means any activity which will, or which may reasonably be expected to, result in the discharge of dredged or fill material into waters of the United States excepting those activities exempted in Section 404 of the Federal Clean Water Act. Temporary emergency permit means a temporary permit that may be issued in certain circumstances specified in section 26- 104(c). Wetland means an area that is inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and under normal circumstances does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions, commonly known as hydrophytic vegetation. Wetlands generally include swamps, marshes, bogs and similar areas. Wetland delineation means the establishment of wetland boundaries by a representative of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers or an authority designated by the Corps. Wetland protection district means all wetlands within the unincorporated area of the county and shown on the generalized wetland map. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 10) Sec. 26-101. - Penalties. Any person who commits, takes part in or assists in any violation of any provision of this article may be fined not more than $500.00 for each offense, or up to 60 days in jail. Each violation shall be a separate offense and, in the case of a continuing violation, each day's continuance shall be deemed to be a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 5) Sec. 26-102. - Findings and purpose. Findings of fact. Wetlands are indispensable and fragile natural resources with significant development constraints due to flooding, erosion and soils limitations. In their natural state, wetlands serve man and nature. Wetlands provide habitat for fish, wildlife and vegetation; water quality maintenance and pollution control; flood control; erosion control; natural resource education; scientific study; and open space and recreational opportunities. In addition, the wise management of forested wetlands is essential to the economic well-being of many communities within the state. Nationally, a considerable number of wetland resources have been lost or impaired by draining, dredging, filling, excavating, building, pollution and other acts. Damaging or destroying wetlands threatens public safety and the general welfare. It is, therefore, necessary to discourage development activities that may adversely affect wetlands by ensuring maximum protection for wetlands located in the unincorporated area of the county. Purpose. The purpose of this article is to promote wetland protection, while taking into account varying ecological, economic development, recreational and aesthetic values. Activities that may damage wetlands should be located on upland sites to the greatest degree practicable as determined through a permitting process. The objective of this article is to protect wetlands from alterations that will significantly affect or reduce their primary functions for water quality, floodplain and erosion control, groundwater recharge, aesthetic, nature and wildlife habitat. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 1) Sec. 26-103. - Wetland protection district. Generalized wetland map. This article shall apply to all lands within wetlands located in the unincorporated area of the county outside the municipalities. The generalized wetland map adopted as part of this article shows the general location of wetlands and should be consulted by persons contemplating activities in or near wetlands. The 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 62/188 (b) (a) (b) (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (c) (1) generalized wetland map, together with all explanatory matter thereon and attached thereto, is adopted by reference and declared to be part of this article. The generalized wetland map shall be on file in the office of the county clerk. Boundaries. The generalized wetland map is a general reference document, and wetland boundaries indicated on the map are approximations. The purpose of the generalized wetland map is to alert developers/landowners that a subject site may be in a jurisdictional wetland or in proximity to a jurisdictional wetland, requiring the developer/landowner to seek U.S. Army Corps of Engineers guidance as to whether a section 404 permit will be required prior to initiation of any development activity on the subject site. The generalized wetland map does not represent precise boundaries of jurisdictional wetlands in the unincorporated area of the county, and cannot serve as a substitute for a delineation of wetland boundaries by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, as required by section 404 of the Clean Water Act, as amended. Any local government action under this does not relieve the landowner from federal or state permitting requirements. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 2) Sec. 26-104. - Local development permits. Local development permit requirements. No regulated activity will be allowed within the wetland protection district without written permission from the permitting officer in the form of a local development permit. Issuance of a local development permit is contingent on full compliance with the terms of this and other applicable regulations. All activities that are not identified in subsection (b) of this section shall be prohibited without prior issuance of a local development permit. If the area proposed for development appears to be located within a wetland protection district boundary, or within 50 feet of the wetland protection district boundary, as determined by the permitting officer from review of the generalized wetland map, a U.S. Army Corps of Engineers determination shall be required. If the Corps determines that wetlands are present on the proposed development site and that a section 404 permit or letter of permission is required, a local development permit will be issued only following receipt by the local permitting officer of a copy of the section 404 permit or letter of permission issued by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Permissible uses (uses as of right). The following uses shall be allowed as of right within a wetland to the extent they are not prohibited by any other ordinance or law, including laws of trespass, and provided they do not require structures, grading, fill, draining or dredging except as provided herein: Conservation or preservation of soil, water, vegetation, fish and other wildlife, provided they do not affect waters of the state or of the United States in such a way that would require an individual 404 permit. Outdoor passive recreational activities, including fishing, bird watching, hiking, boating, horseback riding and canoeing. Forestry practices applied in accordance with best management practices approved by the Georgia Forestry Commission and as specified in section 404 of the Clean Water Act. The continued cultivation of agricultural crops. Agricultural activities shall, however, be subject to best management practices approved by the state department of agriculture. Disturbances of wetlands for agricultural purposes are subject to the Swampbuster Act of the 1985 Farm Bill, and are to be reported to the USDA Farm Service Agency prior to commencement. The pasturing of livestock, provided that riparian wetlands are protected, that soil profiles are not disturbed and that approved agricultural best management practices are followed. Education, scientific research and nature trails. Temporary emergency permit. A temporary emergency permit can be issued by the permitting officer for the following reasons: Maintenance or repair of lawfully located roads or structures and of facilities used in the service of the public 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 63/188 (2) (3) (4) (d) (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) (e) (f) (g) (1) to provide transportation, electric, gas, water, telephone, telegraph, telecommunication or other services, provided that such roads, structures or facilities are not materially changed or enlarged, and written notice prior to the commencement of work has been given to the permitting officer, and provided that the work is conducted using best management practices to ensure that flow and circulation patterns and chemical and biological characteristics of the wetland are not impaired, and that any adverse effect on the aquatic environment will be minimized. Temporary water level stabilization measures associated with ongoing silvicultural operations. Limited ditching, tilling, dredging, excavating or filling done solely for the purpose of maintaining or repairing existing drainage systems necessary for the cultivation of agricultural crops, provided the maintenance or repair activity does not result in the impairment, alteration or loss of wetlands not previously subject to agricultural and silvicultural use under the terms and provisions of subsection (b)(4) of this section. Limited excavating and filling necessary for the repair and maintenance of piers, walkways, nature trails, observation decks, wildlife management shelters, boathouses or other similar water-related structures, provided such facilities and structures are built on pilings to allow unobstructed flow of water and preserve the natural contour of the wetland. Site plans. Applications for a local development permit within the generalized wetland protection district shall include a site plan, drawn to a scale of one inch equals 50 feet, unless a different scale is approved, in advance, by the permitting officer, with the following information: A map of all planned excavation and fill, including calculations of the volume of cut and fill involved with cross sectional drawings showing existing and proposed grades. Elevations, horizontal scale and vertical scale must be shown on the cross sectional drawings. A map of any wetland boundaries occurring within the site must be provided. This boundary may be included on other maps provided by the applicant. Location, dimensions and area of all impervious surfaces, both existing and proposed, on the site and adjacent to the site for a distance of 200 feet. The orientation and distance from the boundaries of the subject site to the nearest bank of an affected perennial stream or water body. Elevation of the site and adjacent lands within 200 feet of the site at contour intervals of no greater than two feet; and no greater than one foot for slopes less than or equal to two percent. Location and detailed design of any spill and leak collection systems designed for the purpose of containing hazardous or toxic materials released accidentally. All proposed temporary disruptions or diversions of local hydrology. Activities to comply with site plan. All development activities or site work conducted after approval of the site plan shall conform with the specifications of such site plan. The site plan may be amended only with approval of the permitting officer. The permitting officer may require additional information deemed necessary to verify compliance with the provisions of this article or to evaluate the proposed use in terms of the purposes of this article. Subdivision approval in the wetland protection district. Any application for subdivision approval shall include a jurisdictional determination approved by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. If the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers determines that wetlands are present and that a section 404 permit or letter of permission is required, subdivision approval will be issued only following issuance of the section 404 permit or letter of permission. Subdivision design options in the wetland protection district. Any subdivision that includes jurisdictional wetlands shall be allowed and encouraged to use the following options: Lot size averaging. Lot size averaging is encouraged in single-family detached subdivisions as a means to work around wetland areas. The permitting officer may allow a reduction in lot size provided the same number of 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 64/188 (2) (h) (i) (j) (k) (l) (1) (2) (3) (a) lots in the same subdivision are oversized by an equal or greater area. The maximum permissible reduction shall not exceed 25 percent of the minimum required lot area. The number of lots with areas reduced shall not exceed 25 percent of the total number of lots in the subdivision. The permitting officer shall allow no more than a 25 percent adjustment of rear, side and front setbacks for each affected lot. Cluster development. Clustering of residential development is encouraged in single-family detached subdivisions as a way around wetland areas. When considering subdivision approval, the permitting officer may allow incorporation of wetland or other significant natural areas as open space in the subdivision plan. Such plans should designate at least 25 percent of the gross land area as open space. Density shall be calculated by subtracting from the total acreage of a parcel all land dedicated or in use for private or public roads, including all vehicular rights-of-way. The resultant acreage will then be divided by the minimum allowed lot size of the district to derive the number of lots permissible. Filing fee. At the time of the application, the applicant shall pay a filing fee specified by the permitting officer. Filing fees of $150.00 shall be required to evaluate the application. However, if, after review of the initial application, it is determined that expert consultants are necessary to provide services pertaining to functional assessment, mitigation and wetland boundary determination, those fees will be in addition to the filing fee. The additional fee may be used to retain expert consultants who will provide services as deemed necessary by the permitting officer. Enforcement authority. The permitting officer is the department, office or individual assigned the responsibility of administering this article. At the time the ordinance from which this article derives is adopted, the administrative authority is vested in the office of the county clerk. Review procedures. The application shall be made to the permitting officer and will be reviewed within 14 days. The review period shall begin upon the permitting officer's written determination that the application is complete. The review period shall include the preparation of findings (approval, conditional approval or disapproval) by the permitting officer. The applicant will receive written notification of the findings of the permitting officer. If the review process is not completed and written findings not released within 30 days, the application is considered to be approved. Appeals. Decisions on permit applications made by the permitting officer may be appealed to the board of commissioners. The appeal must be submitted in writing to the county clerk within ten days of the decision rendered by the permitting officer. A public hearing shall be held by the board of commissioners for appeals. Public announcement of the hearing shall be printed in a local newspaper of general circulation at least 15 days but not more than 45 days prior to the hearing. Any person may offer testimony at the hearing. The decision of the board of commissioners shall be issued within 15 days of the public hearing and may be appealed to the county superior court. Duration of permit validity. If construction described in the development permit has not commenced within six months from the date of issuance, the permit shall expire. If construction described in the development permit is suspended or abandoned after work has commenced, the permit shall expire six months after the date work ceased. Written notice of the pending expiration of the development permit may be issued by the permitting officer, but no such notification is required. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 3) Sec. 26-105. - Monitoring and enforcement. The permitting officer shall have authority to enter upon privately owned land for the purpose of determining whether the provisions of this article are applicable, for the purpose of performing duties required under this article, and for the purpose of taking or causing to be made such examinations, surveys or sampling as the 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 65/188 (1) (2) (3) (b) (c) (d) (e) (f) (a) (b) (1) (2) (3) permitting officer deems necessary. The permitting officer shall have authority to enter the subject site to monitor development and to enforce this article, issue permits hereunder, and address violations or threatened violations hereof by issuance of violation notices, administrative orders and civil and criminal actions. All costs, fees and expenses in connection with such actions may be recovered as damages against the violator. Law enforcement officials or other officials having police powers in the jurisdiction shall have authority to assist the permitting officer with enforcement. The permitting officer shall have authority to issue cease and desist orders in the event of any violation of this article. Cease and desist orders may be appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction, as identified herein. The permitting officer may require a bond with surety and conditions sufficient to secure compliance with the conditions set forth in the permit. The particular amount and the conditions of the bond shall be consistent with the purposes of this article. In the event of a breach of any condition of any such bond, the permitting officer may institute an action in a court of competent jurisdiction upon such bond and prosecute the same to judgment and execution. When the permitting officer determines a building or other structure has been constructed in violation of this article, the violator may, at the discretion of the permitting officer, be required to remove the structure. When removal of vegetative cover, excavation or fill has taken place in violation of this article, the violator may, at the discretion of the permitting officer and as far as practicable, be required to restore the affected land to its original contours and to restore vegetation. If the permitting officer discovers a violation of this article that also constitutes a violation of any provision of the Clean Water Act, 33 USC 26-1251 et seq., as amended, the permitting officer shall issue written notification of the violation to the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the landowner. The permitting officer may suspend or revoke a permit if he finds the applicant has not complied with the conditions or limitations set forth in the permit or has exceeded the scope of the work set forth in the permit. The permitting officer shall cause notice of denial, issuance, conditional issuance, revocation or suspension of a permit to be published in a daily newspaper having a broad circulation in the area where the wetland is located. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 4) Sec. 26-106. - Appeals. Jurisdiction. All final decisions of the board of commissioners concerning denial, approval or conditional approval of a permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article may be appealed to the county superior court. Alternative actions. Based on the proceedings and the county superior court and the decision of such court, the board of commissioners may, within the time specified by the court, elect to: Institute negotiated purchase or condemnation proceedings to acquire an easement or fee interest in the applicant's land; Approve the permit application with lesser restrictions or conditions (i.e., grant a variance); or Institute other appropriate actions ordered by the court that fall within the jurisdiction of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 6) Sec. 26-107. - Amendments. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 66/188 The regulations in this article and the generalized wetland map may from time to time be amended in accordance with procedures and requirements in the general statutes and as new information concerning wetland locations, soils, hydrology, flooding or plant species peculiar to wetlands becomes available. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 7) Sec. 26-108. - Assessment relief. The county board of tax assessors shall consider wetland regulations in determining the fair market value of land. Any owner of an undeveloped wetland who has dedicated an easement or entered into a conservation program with the government or a nonprofit organization restricting activities in a wetland shall have that portion of land assessed consistent with those restrictions. Such landowner shall also be exempted from special assessment on the wetland to defray the cost of municipal improvements such as sanitary sewers, storm sewers and water mains. (Ord. of 11-13-2001, Â§ 8)

div.head: Chapter 30 - HEALTH AND SANITATION
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 30-1â30-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ON-SITE SEWAGE MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS FOOTNOTE(S): Editor's noteâ The adoption date of this article is not available. Sec. 30-31. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: On-site sewage management system means a sewage management system other than a public or community sewage treatment system, whether serving single or multiple buildings, mobile homes, recreational vehicles, residences or other facilities designed or used for human occupancy or congregation. The term "on-site sewage management system" includes conventional septic tank systems, privies, experimental and alternative on-site sewage management systems, portable toilets, and other systems that may be approved by the county board of health. (Ord. No. 87-07-07) Sec. 30-32. - Penalties. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article, if convicted, shall be punished as provided in section 1-17. (Ord. No. 87-07-07) Sec. 30-33. - On-site sewage management system required. (2) 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 67/188 Where public or community sewage treatment systems are not available, the owner, lessee or agent thereof of every building, residence or property designed, used or intended to be used for human occupancy or congregation shall provide an approved onsite sewage management system sufficient for persons normally expected to use or frequent the building, residence or other property for two hours or more. (Ord. No. 87-07-07) Sec. 30-34. - Required standards. New installations of on-site sewage management systems shall meet all standards and provisions as set forth by the county board of health and the state department of human resources. No person may begin the physical development of a lot or structure thereon where an on-site sewage management system will be utilized, nor install a new on-site sewage management system, without first having applied for and obtained from the board of health a construction permit for the installation. No person may cover or use an on-site sewage management system until final inspection has been made by the county board of health to determine compliance with the provisions and standards of construction, and written approval has been issued by the board of health. (Ord. No. 87-07-07) Sec. 30-35. - Prohibited discharge. No person shall allow the unapproved discharge or spillage of sewage, nor shall an on-site sewage management system be used or maintained in such manner that will allow the seepage or discharge of effluent from such system to any ground surface, water well, abandoned well, watercourse, drainage ditch, open trench, canal, storm drain or storm sewer, lake, stream, river, groundwater or other body of water. When, in the opinion of the county board of health, an existing on-site sewage management system presents an eminent or probable threat to public health, use of such system shall be discontinued and corrective measures taken to preserve public health. (Ord. No. 87-07-07) Sec. 30-36. - Administration and enforcement. An individual employed by or acting under the authority of the county health department, county board of health, or county code administrator, together with the county sheriff's department, shall be jointly responsible for the administration and enforcement of this article. (Ord. No. 87-07-07) Sec. 30-37. - Restoration of lands. When removal of vegetative cover, excavation or fill has taken place in violation of this article, the violator shall be required to restore the affected land to its original contours and to restore vegetation, as far as practicable.

div.head: Chapter 34 - MOBILE HOMES
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 34-1â34-29. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME PARKS 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 68/188 (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (1) (2) Sec. 34-30. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Mobile home means a generic term for a factory-built dwelling unit built on a permanent chassis and made to be readily transportable on its own running gear in one or more sections totaling no less than 576 square feet which is subject to the Georgia Motor Vehicle Title Registration Act (O.C.G.A. Â§ 40-2-1 et seq.) and meeting the construction and safety standards of the national code administered by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. The term "mobile home" does not include recreational vehicles. Every mobile home shall: Be suitable for yearround occupancy; Be placed on a permanent masonry foundation or other substantial foundation that will comply with the state minimum building code for the erection and support of mobile homes and to be substantially anchored to its site also in compliance with the state minimum building code; Be connected to a water system approved by either the county health department or the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division, as the case may be, and a letter or certification of such approval shall be presented to the county inspector; Be connected to an approved waste disposal system approved by either the county health department or the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division, as the case may be, and a letter or certification of such approval shall be presented to the county inspector; Have all electrical supply systems and connections that comply with the current state minimum electric code; and Be landscaped with trees, shrubs, and other plan material substantially equal to or better than one-family dwelling within 500 feet. The area between the bottom perimeter of the mobile home and the ground shall be covered with material that is suitable and adequately functional to adequately protect the under side of the mobile home and to keep the mobile home from being unsightly. The owner of the mobile home is responsible for the skirting. Mobile home park means: A parcel of land which has been planned and improved for the placement of two or more mobile homes for nontransient use and occupancy or for rental occupancy. A conditional use permit shall be required for the establishment of a mobile home park. The term "park" includes the term "community." The owner of a tract or parcel of land who has placed a mobile home on that tract or parcel of land as his residence may place one additional mobile home on the parcel of land, as long as the second mobile home is not rested, and the two mobile homes located on the tract of land shall not be classified as a mobile home park. Mobile home space means a plot of ground within a mobile home park designated for the accommodation of not more than one mobile home of single-family occupancy. Modular home means a factory fabricated transportable building consisting of building units designed to be incorporated at a building site on a permanent foundation as a permanent structure with the appearance of a conventional on site constructed building and to be used for residential purposes. A modular home is not a mobile home. The term "modular home" includes the terms "manufactured home" and "prefabricated home." Every modular home shall: 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 69/188 (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) (a) (b) (c) Be suitable for yearround occupancy; Be placed on a permanent masonry foundation or other substantial foundation that will comply with the state minimum building code for the erection and support of mobile homes and be substantially fixed to its site also in compliance with the state minimum building code; Be connected to a water system approved by either the county health department or the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division, as the case may be, and a letter or certification of such approval shall be presented to the county inspector; Be connected to an approved waste disposal system approved by either the county health department or the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division, as the case may be, and a letter or certification of such approval shall be presented to the county inspector; Have all electrical supply systems and connections that comply with the current state minimum electric code; Be landscaped with trees, shrubs, and other plan material substantially equal to or better than one-family dwelling within 500 feet; and Meet the general construction and safety standards of the latest edition of the state minimum building codes. The area between the bottom perimeter of the mobile home and the ground shall be covered with material that is suitable and adequately functional to adequately protect the underside of the mobile home and to keep the mobile home from being unsightly. The owner of the mobile home is responsible for the skirting. Rent or rental means any enumeration, whether in money, barter, or kind, that is given or received as consideration for the occupancy of a mobile home or the occupancy of a tract, space or parcel of land upon which a mobile home is situated. Service building means a building that houses facilities such as recreational, maintenance, laundry, and office structures necessary to the successful development and management of a mobile home park. Travel trailer means a motorized camper, converted bus, tent-trailer or other similar vehicular or portable structure used or designed for temporary portable housing or occupancy while on vacation, recreational, or other trip and provided with sleeping accommodations. The travel trailer shall not be used for permanent housing or a permanent residence. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 1, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-31. - Penalties and incentives. Failure to obtain a permit. If any person commences a mobile home park without first obtaining a permit, the person shall be subject to revocation of any permit or other authorization received from the county and associated with the establishment of the mobile home park. Stop work orders. Upon notice from the county inspector, work on the mobile home contrary to the provision of this article, or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, shall be immediately stopped. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, his authorized agent, or the person in charge of constructing the mobile home park on the property, and shall state the conditions under which work way be resumed. Where an emergency exists, no written notice shall be required. Civil penalties. Any person violating any provision of this article or stop work order shall be liable for a civil penalty of not less than $500.00 per day, a sentence of imprisonment not exceeding 60 days in jail, or both fine and jail, or work alternative. Each day the violation continues shall constitute a separate offence. All violators issued a summons shall be tried in the magistrate court of the county. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 23, 6-11-1996; Res. of 4-12-2005) Sec. 34-32. - Purpose. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 70/188 (a) (b) (a) (b) (c) (d) (1) (2) (3) (4) The purpose of this article is to prescribe the manner in which a mobile home park may be created and operated in the county for the health, safety, and welfare of those who reside in the mobile home park and for the preservation of the health, safety, and welfare of all citizens of the county, and to provide certain standards and criteria so that the health, safety and welfare of all citizens may be preserved. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-33. - Conict with other regulations. Whenever the regulations of this article require a greater width or size of yards, courts, or other open space, or an imposed other restrictive standards that are required in or under any other structure or ordinance, the regulations and requirements of this article shall govern. Whenever the provisions of any other statute or ordinance require more restrictive standards than are required by this article, the provisions of such statute or ordinance shall govern. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 2, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-34. - Application for permission to develop or maintain. It shall be unlawful for any person to develop or maintain a mobile home park in the county unless it is duly permitted and pursuant to the provisions of this section. The application for the development of a mobile home park shall have attached to the application proof that all county taxes due the county from the application have been paid in full, and no permit may be issued until all taxes due from the applicant are paid in full. The board of commissioners may recommend approval of a planned mobile home park when all conditions precedent to this article have been met. An application and all accompanying plans and supporting data shall be filed in triplicate with the county inspector at least two weeks prior to a regular meeting of the board of commissioners. The application shall be in writing, and it shall include the following information: The name and address of the applicant; The location and description of the boundaries of the property intended for planned mobile home park development; A complete mobile home park plan showing all existing conditions and proposed site development as required in this section including preliminary plans of all buildings, improvements and facilities constructed or to be constructed within the mobile home park (on a topographic map). Such plan shall be drawn at a scale of one inch equals not more than 100 feet; Any other information reasonably requested by the county inspector to determine the proposed park's compliance with legal requirements, the effect which the proposed park may have on its environment and the compatibility of the adjacent area for park development. The application shall be verified by the applicant, and the board of commissioners are authorized to revoke the mobile home permit in the event any false statements are made on the application. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 3, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-35. - Dimensional and site development requirements; mobile home park plan. The mobile home park plan shall show or propose all requirements listed in this article, and in addition, all such requirements shall be complied with before a certificate or occupancy may be issued. The mobile home park plan shall, at a minimum, conform to the following: 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 71/188 (1) (2) (3) (a) (b) (c) (d) (1) Frontage and area. A mobile home park shall front for at least 100 feet on a major public thoroughfare and shall h area of at least five buildable acres. Entrances and exits. The entrances and exits to the mobile home park shall be from a major public thoroughfare. All entrance and exit streets shall have a right-of-way width of at least 60 feet and a surface width of at least 28 feet and a distance of at least 100 feet from the public thoroughfare extending into the park, and after the first 100 feet shall be deemed an interior street. Park boundaries. A mobile home park shall be bounded with a ten-foot buffer strip along all of the exterior property lines of the park not bounding a major public thoroughfare. The buffer strip shall be planted with evergreen trees or shrubs that grow at least eight feet in height and provide a visual screen. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 4, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-36. - Minimum number of mobile home spaces. Any legal entity that owns and rents two or more spaces shall be required to obtain a permit and will be subject to the terms of this article. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 5, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-37. - Required lot (mobile home space) area. Each mobile home space shall contain at least 4,500 square feet of area, and will also be of sufficient size to comply with the county and state health laws. There shall not be more than eight spaces per gross acre. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 6, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-38. - Yard requirements. Each mobile home space shall be at least 52 feet wide and clearly defined. There shall be a 20-foot side yard for each mobile home space, the side yard being the space parallel to the longest dimension of the home. There shall be a 40-foot minimum distance between homes, side-to-side, and a 40-foot minimum distance between homes, end-to-end. No mobile home shall be located closer than 25 feet to any street and within the park or within 40 feet of any exterior public street. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 7, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-39. - Drainage. The mobile home park shall be located on a well-drained and properly graded site. The site drainage improvements shall meet the county's soil, erosion, and sedimentation ordinance. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 8, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-40. - Interior streets and driveways. All mobile home parks shall contain a street system designed to provide convenient circulation within the park, and shall have unobstructed access to a public street or highway in accordance with requirements of the county. The following requirements shall apply to the development of a mobile home park's street system: All interior streets shall have a right-of-way width of at least 40 feet unless a greater width for drainage purposes is required. The minimum surface width shall be 22 feet for an interior street; 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 72/188 (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (a) (b) (1) (2) (3) (4) (a) (b) (c) All mobile home park streets shall be provided with a smooth, graveled all-weather surface having a minimum wi which shall be durable and well drained under normal weather conditions; All mobile home park streets shall be maintained in a state of good repair at all times by the park owner; Street base and surface construction materials shall be as required by the county's street and read standards. Written approval of the street system by the county inspector shall be required before the first mobile home building permit will be issued. Driveways on individual spaces shall be at least eight feet in width; All structures located on the space shall observe the required setback and distance requirements. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 9, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-41. - O-drive parking. No automobile parking shall be permitted on that portion of the interior street system designated as the entrance or exit portion and being that portion of the street that is 60 feet in width and 100 feet deep as measured from the major public thoroughfare. At least two automobile spaces shall be provided for each mobile home space. The parking spaces shall be provided on the individual spaces or on street parking lanes or on an off-street parking lot that is located within 200 feet of the mobile home spaces the parking lot serves. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 10, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-42. - Signs. The following nonflashing and nonanimated signs are permitted under the conditions specified: Park identification sign. One mobile home park identification sign shall be required, not to exceed 24 square feet in area, for the purpose of denoting the name of the mobile home park. Mobile home lot identification sign. One mobile home lot identification sign not exceeding one square foot in area shall be required for each mobile home lot. Such sign shall indicate the name, address, and lot number of the occupant of the mobile home. Street signs. All streets in the mobile home park shall be named in conformity with the this article and street signs shall be erected at the park owner's expense. The sign identifying the lot shall be visible from the street. Visibility. No sign shall be located so as to impede vehicular visibility at any intersection of street lines with one another or the edge of driveways with street lines. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 11, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-43. - Improvements to mobile homes and mobile home spaces. No permanent addition of any kind shall be built onto or become a part of any mobile home, with the exception of awnings and porches, which shall comply with building code requirements in effect in the county. Each space shall contain a permanent mobile home stand constructed of a suitable subgrade material to support the mobile home. The chassis of each mobile home shall be supported on an adequate masonry foundation. Such masonry foundation shall meet the minimum requirements of the state minimum building code. Each mobile home space shall be given to lot number and accordingly marked to be visible from the street providing access thereto. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 12, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-44. - Special conditions and safeguards. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 73/188 (a) In recommending approval of any planned mobile home park, the board of commissioners may attach special conditions and safeguards to protect both the occupants of the park and the occupants of surrounding property, including such matters as protection against noise, lights, dust, and fire. Where required to service these ends, walls, plantings, surfacing, or other natural or artificial means for protection may reasonably be required as part of such special conditions on which the recommendation for approval of a mobile home park is based. Failure to meet such conditions shall be grounds for refusal of issuance of a certificate of occupancy. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 13, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-45. - Minimum size and sanitation facilities of mobile homes. No mobile home which has less than 576 square feet of floor space and which does not contain a built-in bathroom with water closet, lavatory and shower or tub which are in working condition, or manufactured seven years prior to date of permit, shall be placed in a planned mobile home park. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 14, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-46. - Lighting. All interior drives and walkways within the mobile home park shall be lighted at night with electric lamps spaced at intervals of no more than 150 feet. Such lighting shall meet the minimum requirements of the state mobile home regulations. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 15, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-47. - Refuse collection facilities. Each mobile home park shall be provided with a sanitary method of solid waste collection and disposal meeting the requirements of the state and the county solid waste ordinance. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 16, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-48. - Service buildings. Service buildings such as shelters, restrooms, management offices and storage facilities are permitted in each mobile home park and are subject to the following requirements: Such buildings and their parking areas shall not occupy more than ten percent of the gross land area of the park. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 17, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-49. - Existing mobile home parks. Mobile home parks existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived may be continued by the owner who owned the mobile home park as of the date of such ordinance, and maintained except that such mobile home park shall not be enlarged or expanded unless such enlargement or expansion is in full compliance with this article; provided, however, the owner shall comply with the requirements of section 34-53; and provided further, each mobile home park owner, and each owner of a mobile home, shall comply with the skirting requirements of this article within six months of the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 18, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-50. - Development compliance. At least 100 percent of each phase, enlargement or expansion of all planned spaces, as well as all streets, utilities, and other required improvements necessary to serve them pursuant to this article, shall be completely constructed 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 74/188 (b) (a) (b) (c) (d) (e) (a) (b) (c) (a) (b) (c) (d) (e) according to the mobile home park plan approved by the board of commissioners before the first mobile home building permit will be issued. Failure of the developer or applicant to construct this minimum phase within two years after approval by the board of commissioners shall cause such approval to expire. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 19, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-51. - Inspection. The building inspector is authorized and directed to make inspections to determine the condition of mobile home parks located within the county, in order that such inspector may perform the duty of safeguarding the health and safety of occupants of mobile home parks and of the general public. The building inspector shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this article. The building inspector shall have the power to inspect the register containing a record of all mobile homes and occupants using the mobile home park. It shall be the duty of the owners or occupants of mobile home parks, or of the person in charge thereof, to give the building inspector free access to such premises at reasonable times for the purpose of inspection. It shall be the duty of every occupant of a mobile home park to give the owner thereof, or the owner's agent or employee, access to any part of such mobile home park or its premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with this article or with any lawful order issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 20, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-52. - Decal required. All persons owning a mobile home located in the county on January 1 of each year shall obtain from the tax commissioner a decal before April 1, as provided in O.C.G.A. Â§ 48-5-493. This requirement pertains to all mobile homes, including these exempted from taxation by homestead exemption or other provisions of state law. The mobile home decal shall be affixed to each mobile home in such manner as to cause the decal to be easily visible for inspection. Owners of mobile homes locating their mobile homes in the county after January 1 of any year shall be required to report the location of their mobile home to the tax commissioner's office and to the building inspector within ten working days. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 21, 6-11-1996) Sec. 34-53. - Title reports by mobile home park operators. Every owner and operator of a mobile home park is required to give to the county inspector an inventory of all mobile homes located in the park as of January 1 of each year, beginning January of 1996. The inventory shall be delivered to the county inspector not later than January 20 of each year. Every owner, manager, and operator of a mobile home park is required to report to the county inspector any mobile home moved into the mobile home park after January 1 of each year. Every owner, manager, and operator of a mobile home park shall furnish to the county inspector an updated lot map of each mobile home park, and changes to the map shall be reported by January 20 of each year. Every owner, manager, and operator of a mobile home park is required to notify the county inspector of any change in ownership or any change in the name of any mobile home park within 30 days of such change. The county inspector will notify the tax commissioner of the information that has been furnished to him by the 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 75/188 (f) owner and operator of the mobile home park as may be needed by the tax commissioner for the updating of the tax commissioner's records. This section applies to all mobile home park owners, including those in existence prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived. (Ord. No. 96-11-06(B), Â§ 22, 6-11-1996) Secs. 34-54â34-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - MINIMUM HEALTH AND SAFETY STANDARDS FOR PRE-OWNED MANUFACTURED HOMES FOOTNOTE(S): Editor's noteâ Sections 1â6 of an ordinance adopted Oct. 12, 2010, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as a new art. III, Â§Â§ 34-71â34-76 was at the discretion of the editor. Sec. 34-71. - Denitions. The following words, terms, or phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: Applicant means any person seeking to install a pre-owned manufactured home in the unincorporated area of Marion County. Building inspector means the person appointed, employed, or otherwise designated as the director of planning, permits and inspections; the county building official or any of his or her assistants. Certificate of occupancy means a document issued by the building inspector certifying that a pre-owned manufactured home is in compliance with applicable requirements set forth by this article, and indicating it to be in a condition suitable for residential occupancy. Guarantee of condition bond means a surety bond to guarantee that the affidavit and photographs required by subsections 34-73(1)a. and b. of this article reasonably portray or represents the existing condition of the pre-owned manufactured home proposed for relocation. In lieu of the bond, a cash deposit may be deposited with the county. Install means to construct a foundation system and to place or erect a manufactured home on such foundation system. Such term includes, without limitation, supporting, blocking, leveling, securing, or anchoring such manufactured home and connecting multiple or expandable sections of such manufactured home. Jurisdiction means the unincorporated areas of Marion County, Georgia. Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this paragraph except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the secretary of housing and urban development and complies with the standards established under the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C. Section 5401 et seq. Pre-owned manufactured home means any manufactured home that has been previously used as a residential dwelling and has been titled. (Ord. of 10-12-2010, Â§ 1) (3) 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 76/188 (1) a. b. c. d. (2) (3) (4) (5) (1) (2) (3) Sec. 34-72. - Conditions. All pre-owned manufactured homes located in the jurisdiction shall bear a label certifying it was constructed in compliance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C. Section 5401 et seq. (the HUD Code) and shall be installed in accordance with O.C.G.A. Â§ 8-2-160 et seq. (Ord. of 10-12-2010, Â§ 2) Sec. 34-73. - Permitting, inspection, certicate of occupancy und fees. A permit shall be required to locate a pre-owned manufactured home in the jurisdiction. Permit. To obtain a permit, applicants shall provide to the building inspector: An affidavit signed by the applicant that the pre-owned manufactured home meets health and safety standards required by this Act; Photographs of the interior and exterior of the pre-owned manufactured home providing evidence that home meets the minimum health and safety standards of section 34-74 of this article; A $3,000.00 refundable guarantee of condition bond or $3,000.00 refundable cash deposit; and The permit and inspection fee required by subsection (4) of this section. Inspection. Upon receipt of a permit, applicants may relocate the manufactured home on a residential site for the purposes of inspection. Applicant shall arrange for an inspection to be held once the installation of the manufactured home is complete. Certificate of occupancy. A certificate of occupancy shall be issued to the applicant at such time that the building inspector certifies that the requirements of this article have been met. Fee. A permit and inspection fee of $100.00 shall be charged to the applicant to cover the cost to the county to process the permit application and inspect the pre-owned manufactured home. Such fee shall cover the initial inspection and one followup inspection. The applicant shall be charged $100.00 for each additional followup inspection that may be necessary, Alternative inspection. At the request of the applicant, the building inspector may, at his or her discretion, inspect a pre-owned manufactured home prior to its being relocated if the home is then located at another site within the county. (Ord. of 10-12-2010, Â§ 3) Sec. 34-74. - Minimum health and safety standards. All preowned manufactured homes shall comply with the following before being issued a certificate of occupancy by the building inspector: HUD Code. Every pre-owned manufactured home located in the jurisdiction shall be in compliance with the Federal Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act, 42 U.S.C. 5401-5445 (the HUD Code) and shall not have been altered in such a way that the home no longer meets the HUD Code. Interior condition. Every floor, interior wall, and ceiling of a pre-owned manufactured home shall be in sound condition. Doors and windows shall be operable, watertight and in good working condition. The floor system shall be in sound condition and free of warping, holes, water damage, or deterioration. Exterior condition. The exterior of all pre-owned manufactured homes shall be free of loose or rotting boards or timbers and any other conditions that might admit rain or moisture to the interior portions of the walls or to occupied spaces. The exterior siding shall be free of rot and rust. Roofs shall be structurally sound and have no obvious defects that might admit rain or cause moisture to collect on the interior portion of the home. 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 77/188 (4) (5) (6) (7) (8) (9) (10) (a) (b) (c) Sanitary facilities. Every plumbing fixture, water, and waste pipe of a pre-owned manufactured home shall be in a sanitary working condition when properly connected, and shall be free from leaks and obstructions. Each home shall contain a kitchen sink. Each bathroom shall contain a lavatory and water closet. At least one bathroom shall contain a tub and/or shower facilities. Each of these fixtures shall be checked upon being connected to ensure they are in good working condition. Heating systems. Heating shall be safe and in working condition. Un-vented heaters shall be prohibited. Electrical systems. Electrical systems (switches, receptacles, fixtures, etc.) shall be properly installed and wired and shall be in working condition. Distribution panels shall be in compliance with the approved listing, complete with required breakers, with all unused openings covered with solid covers approved and listed for that purpose. The home shall be subject to an electrical continuity test to assure that, all metallic parts are properly bonded. Hot water supply. Bach home shall contain a water heater in safe and working condition. Egress windows. Each bedroom of a manufactured home shall have at least one operable window of sufficient size to allow egress if necessary. Ventilation. The kitchen in the home shall have at least one operating window or other ventilation device. Smoke detectors. Each pre-owned manufactured home shall contain one operable battery-powered smoke detector in each bedroom and in the kitchen, which must be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. (Ord. of 10-12-2010, Â§ 4) Sec. 34-75. - Enforcement. Permanent connection to utilities shall not be approved until the building inspector has issued a certificate of occupancy. Owners of pre-owned manufactured homes that are not in compliance upon a third inspection shall have their permit revoked and shall be required to remove the home front the jurisdiction at their own expense. The guarantee of condition bond or cash deposit will be forfeited after 90 days from the date of inspection, unless all conditions and standards are met prior to the end of the 90 days or an extension has been issued in writing by the building inspector. (Ord. of 10-12-2010, Â§ 5) Sec. 34-76. - Penalties. Failure to remove a pre-owned manufactured home from the jurisdiction upon failure to receive a certificate of occupancy shall be punishable by a fine of $500.00. Each day any violation under this article continues shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord. of 10-12-2010, Â§ 6)

div.head: Chapter 38 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 38-1. - Penalty assessment for jail construction and stang. Pursuant to the provisions of an act of the legislature called the Jail Construction and Staffing Act and identified as 1989 Ga. Laws, page 1753 (O.C.G.A. Â§ 15-21-90 et seq.), the county hereby levies a ten percent penalty on every fine levied in the county. The provisions of said act are hereby put into legal effect. It shall be the responsibility of every person, agency or legal entity collecting fines to add an additional ten percent onto the fine imposed by the court or fine imposing entity or tribunal and collect the same 5/30/2019 Marion County, GA Code of Ordinances 78/188 from the person being required to pay the fine and penalty. Such person or legal entity collecting the ten percent penalty shall, by the tenth day of the month following the month in which such penalties are collected, pay to the county governing authorities said sums collected. Such funds shall be deposited in a county jail fund for the sole purpose of being used for constructing, operating, and staffing of jails, correctional institutions, and detention facilities by the county. The ten percent surcharge shall begin being imposed as of January 1, 1990. (Res. of 7-11-1989)

div.head: Chapter 46 - ROADS AND BRIDGES
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 46-1. - National Highway System. The Georgia Department of Transportation take the necessary steps to revise the National Highway System as shown on the sketch map numbered 069R and as described as follows: Add to the National Highway System as a STRAHNET Route a section of State Route 26, beginning at the junction of State Route 26 with State Routes 1 and 520/U.S. Routes 27 and 280 in Chattahoochee County and extending in a generally easterly direction along State Route 26 via the Marion County Line, Buena Vista, Schley County Line, Ellaville, Macon County Line, Oglethorpe, Montezuma, Houston County Line, Pulaski County Line, Hawkinsville, Bleckley County Line, Cochran and the Laurens County Line to its interchange with Interstate 16/State Route 404 for 112.29 miles/180.67 km. (Ord. of 6-12-2007) Secs. 46-2â46-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - HAULING AND LOGGING DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 46-31. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Access site means any temporary roadway, drive, structure, fill or device, existing or constructed, that is used or employed for the purpose of crossing, travel upon or use of county road rights-of-way.
